title: Before 29 August 2020, will the German Bundesbank be barred from participating in the European Central Bank's (ECB's) PSPP quantitative easing program?
preds: My answer is that the Bundesbank will NOT be barred from participating in the ECB PSPP. Hence, 0 probability of a Yes outcome.  Three reasons for this; a) this would potentially bring legal chaos into the EU as it questions which court has authority in EU, the ECJ or the national courts? Hence, the possibility of a collapse of EU treaties, and the potential undermining of the ECB's ability to provide monetary support (see https://bit.ly/3eZ5mWQ ) and b) the German Bundestag has confirmed to the Constitutional Court that the ECB's PSPP program does indeed satisfy the proportionality requirement stipulated by the judges (see https://bit.ly/39EB4Yj) Lastly, c) the German Contitutional Court could not instruct the ECB to make changes as it has no jurisdiction over the ECB. Judging by @ChristineLagarde, ECB President, comments (https://bit.ly/2EctEjU) on 7/7/20 the ECB seems convinced that the proportionality element of the German Federal Court has been answered by the Bundersbank, with supporting information from the ECB. That being the case, there is very little likelihood, within this time frame, of the Bundersbank being excluded from the PSPP program

From Aug 7: "The Bundesbank's statement that it believes the requirements of the German Constitutional Court (GCC) regarding ECB quantitative easing (QE) have been fulfilled means Germany's central bank will continue its asset purchase operations without disruption ... the Bundesbank, the largest national central bank in the Eurosystem, would continue its asset purchase operations under the PSPP beyond the 5 August deadline." https://www.fitchratings.com/research/sovereigns/bundesbank-to-maintain-bond-buying-after-court-response-07-08-2020

According to Ratings agency, the Bundesbank  will continue to its assets purchase program, but does not rule out a future ruling by the German Federal Constitutional Court.
The Bundesbank understands that  the GCC has jurisdiction over the Bank, but not over the ECB and Eurozone monetary policy.

German Constitutional Court took to task the German government and the German central bank, the Deutsche Bundesbank, for not having challenged the ECB’s unorthodox monetary policy.  The court found that the ECB likely exceeded its authority by not respecting the Eurozone’s principle of “proportionality.”  The court is now threatening to preclude the Bundesbank, the ECB’s largest member bank, from participating in the ECB’s bond-buying program unless the Bundesbank provides a convincing legal defense of the ECB’s actions. ECB’s immediate reaction was to declare that it was subject to the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice and not to that of the German Constitutional Court.  ECB has expanded the program under dispute. It enlarged its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Program (PEPP) from €750 billion to €1,350 billion.  ECB is choosing to exercise complete discretion as to which countries’ government bonds it will buy and in what proportion. It is unlikely that the disproportionate amount of Italian government debt that the ECB has bought over the last two months will have escaped the German court’s notice
